sub_title: PhD Researcher@ Vrije Universiteit, Amsterdam: Land use & Pyrogeography in Europe
summary:
I am currently pursuing a PhD in Environmental Geography from the Institute for Environmental Studies (IVM) at Vrije Universiteit in Amsterdam. 

With broad experience as a project manager, researcher, and educator, my research has focused on managing multiple-use landscapes for people and the environment.  I bring experience in international development and natural resource management from my time spent working for the US Forest Service International Program in Central Africa, as well as Tetra Tech ARD, and years spent as an agribusiness extension agent with the US Peace Corps in rural Mali and Burkina Faso.

This background contributes to my current project looking at landscape scale to manage wildfire risk in Europe in the present and future, funded by the FirEUrisk project (Horizon 2020). I will be mapping relevant areas in which certain land management strategies, such as silvopastoralism and brush clearing, could be most effective and using CLUmondo to model land use scenarios relevant to climate risk.

My master’s research focused on forest health, invasive species management, and species distribution modelling at the University of Vermont’s Rubenstein School. This research, published in the journals Forest Ecology and Management and Environmental Entomology, was funded by the US Forest Service and a grant from the Vermont Clean Energy Fund. The research contributed to the use of Leucopis spp. as a biological control for the hemlock woolly adelgid (Tsuga spp.) and understanding the opportunities and risks of invasive species transport in the wood pellet supply chain.

 I have experience working in English, French, Bambara and Spanish.

I also helped to organize and support discussions on diversity and inclusion, broadly, and dissolving power structures built into international development rhetoric and dynamics.', 'title': 'Staff Associate', 'employment_type': 'Full-time'}]}, {'company': {'id': 8706, 'name': 'University of Vermont', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C510BAQFYnDeVVaTc3A/company-logo_400_400/0/1519855947375?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=ERTxWc8cEHSjdykDr9zBmssWFkjQ3SK5P8ekjOsild8', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/school/university-of-vermont/', 'employees': {'start': 1001, 'end': 5000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}, 'end': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Burlington, Vermont', 'date': {'start': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}, 'end': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'company': 'University of Vermont', 'description': 'At the Rubenstein School of Environment and Natural Resources at the University of Vermont, I conducted research at the intersection of invasive species, forestry, and alternative energy in three studies.
Invasive ecology was explored through an assessment of two potential biological control agents of hemlock woolly adelgid.  These two species of silver fly from the Pacific Northwest (Leucopis argenticollis and L. piniperda) were examined for temporal and spatial resource partitioning patterns and niche characteristics that would applicable to the release procedures used in the eastern United States.  
Leucopis spp. exhibited sinusoidal patterns of daily emergence when examined over a 29-day period, with peak daily abundances that were inversely related.  Spatially, however, landscape-scale and climatic indicators were not significant in predicting the presence of Leucopis spp. in the Pacific Northwest.  This adds important information about niche dynamics of Leucopis spp. in the Pacific Northwest, which may have logistical and operational implications for their use in the USDA Forest Service’s Hemlock Woolly Adelgid Initiative.
Additionally, the potential opportunities and risks of using wood that has been impacted by invasive species and pests was explored through a literature analysis focused on three species posing a threat to northeastern US forests: emerald ash borer, hemlock woolly adelgid, and southern pine beetle. Based on this review, I concluded that although opportunities for the use of this wood are sometimes recognized, the phytosanitary risks in feedstock pre-treatment are not being directly addressed in US-related literature.  These studies provide important evidence for adaptive solutions to forest pests that consider both forest health and forest economics.', 'title': 'Forest Health Researcher', 'employment_type': 'Full-time'}]}, {'company': {'id': 5416, 'name': 'U.S. Forest Service', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/D560BAQF0XaF15-r4ww/company-logo_400_400/0/1688314400086?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=G6obbGWYE1Or_jBgCWCf_DfcKJw0irPTG_LzLnlnRL0', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/usda-forest-service/', 'employees': {'start': 10001, 'end': None}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Washington D.C.  I also coordinated USFS SilvaCarbon's technical programming in Africa, specifically focused on development of a national forest monitoring system and nationally determined contributions for Cameroon, leading to a strong network in the climate change world.
My responsibilities also included oversight of technical field missions on subjects such as soil carbon storage in Congo’s peat-lands, forest inventory and biodiversity trainings, and public-private partners for forest management.
